intro: Gilia micrantha var. longituba, commonly known as the long-tube gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and showy, tubular flowers. The flowers are typically pink to purple in color and are adapted for pollination by long-tongued insects such as bees and butterflies. This plant thrives in dry, well-drained soils and is often found in desert and semi-desert environments. It is a herbaceous annual or biennial plant that produces small, capsule-like fruits containing numerous seeds.
